Award.AwardTitle: REU Site: Research Experience for Undergraduates in Astrophysics, Nuclear and Particle Physics
Award.AbstractNarration: This award supports the renewal of the Research Experience for Undergraduates (REU) program hosted at Wayne State University. The program consists of a preparation phase involving a one-hour course given over the winter to student participants, followed by ten weeks of summer research at either Wayne State University or Fermi National Laboratory (Batavia, IL) in topics including Astrophysics, Nuclear Physics, or Particle Physics. The one-hour course introduces the students to the physical, mathematical and computational concepts relevant for the summer experience. It includes a computer training homework and an ethics component. The participants then merge with other existing REU programs at each site for social activities and lectures on various scientific topics. Students are mentored by PhD researchers working on leading edge physics topics and/or technologies chosen for good mentorship qualities as well as their leadership in their respective scientific fields. Students are required to submit a report in the form of a paper at the end of their experience and deliver oral presentations.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Our REU program is specifically tailored as an introductory experience for beginning undergraduates. We often work with students who have no prior connection to science, and are often first in their family to experience higher education. Our aim is to introduce them to the notion that they can have a scientific career if they choose. The program consists of three stages: (1) a preparation phase involving weekly one-hour course given during the winter semester to student participants, followed by (2) ten weeks of summer research at either Wayne State University or Fermi National Laboratory (Batavia, IL) in topics including Astrophysics, Nuclear Physics, or Particle Physics. The one-hour course introduces the students to the physical, mathematical and computational concepts relevant for the summer experience. It includes a computer training homework and an ethics component. The participants then arrive for a summer program at WSU and/or FNAL and SLAC. Students are mentored by PhD researchers working on leading edge physics topics and/or technologies chosen for good mentorship qualities as well as their leadership in their respective scientific fields. Finally, during the evaluation stage (3), the students are required to submit a report in the form of a paper at the end of their experience and deliver oral presentations. This project is educational in nature, so research results obtained by the participants, while important, are secondary to the educational outcomes.

            REU participants from WSU delivered presentations at the WSU Undergraduate Research Conference and 7th/8th/9th Annual Wayne State University Undergraduate Physics Research Conferences, as well as topical conferences in astrophysics, particle and nuclear physics. One student received undergraduate award covering her participation in the 2013 Fall Meeting of the Division of Nuclear Physics of the APS. Among research contributions, the participants of REU have developed applications of perturbative techniques to study jets at ALICE, performed analyses of rare decays of W-boson, and participated in projects related to developing new methods and experimental designs in astronomical observations. Each year, there was an excursion to the site of the National Superconducting Cyclotron Laboratory at Michigan State University.

     We pay particular attention to members of groups underrepresented in science. Participating students acquired basic skills in modern research and laboratory techniques, provided exposure to scientific research for students who will go on in other fields, gave students a clearer idea of their options for a future in research, motivated students toward careers in science, and improved students' literacy as well as written and oral communication skills. The majority of participants (who are undergraduate students majoring in physics) are planning to continue their education in graduate schools.
